Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: People — According to the principles of ‘Leave No One Behind’ (LNOB), ensure that all human beings can fulfil their potential in dignity, equity, and equality in a healthy environment (SDGs 1–5)
Outcome: All human beings are further enabled to fulfil their potential in dignity, equity, and equality in a healthy environment.
Output: Improved quality of essential social and protection services focusing on government institutional capacity and multisectoral collaboration.
Sub-Output: Improved Quality of Health Services provided by healthcare workers in different healthcare facilities
Implementation partners: Saudi Food and Drug Authority, Saudi Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.,6.4 By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 6 Clean Water and Sanitation
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: SDG indicator 3.7 & 6.1 are gender quality based
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: % of Exp on health to ooverall household exp is a measure of free access to quality health services (Indicator 3.8.2)
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY 1 : Achieving Social Cohesion, Protection and Inclusion
Outcome: Outcome 1.3 : People in Iraq participate in and benefit from effective mechanisms – at national, subnational and community levels – that prevent, mitigate and manage conflict, and contribute to social cohesion and peaceful coexistence, with particular focus on women and youth leadership in decision-making, peace-building and reconciliation processes.
Output: Output 1.3.2 : Community mechanisms, including schools and social groups, are supported to inclusively engage community members to contribute to peacebuilding and social cohesion.
Sub-Output: Key Activity 1.3.2.41: LPMs improve their capacity to lead dialogue and discussion among different groups of people in their communities
SDG Targets: 10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY 3 : Promoting Effective, Inclusive and Efficient Institutions and Services
Outcome: Outcome 3.1 : Strengthened institutions and systems deliver people-centred, evidence and needs-based equitable and inclusive gender- and age-responsive services, especially for the most vulnerable populations, with particular focus on advocating for women’s leadership in decision-making processes.
Output: Output  3.1.1 : National and sub national information management and research systems increase the generation, analysis and dissemination of quality and timely disaggregated data essential for evidence-based service delivery
Sub-Output: Key Activity 3.1.1.35: Training of different level staff on nutrition in emergency (provide services, situation assessment and analysis, and monitoring and evaluation)
Contributing partners: Government of Canada, Government of Germany, Government of the United States of America, JAPAN FUNDS, KFW - GERMANY, NUTRITION INTERNATIONAL, UNICEF Nutrition Thematic Fund
SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger, 3 Good Health and Well-being

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Outcome: The Kingdom of Bahrain plays an enhanced role in international and regional partnerships for sustainable development, including peace and security initiatives, and to expand South-South cooperation
Output: 13. Civil Society Organizations, private sectors and relevant institutions are engaged in the promotion and advancement of the Sustainable Development Goals.
Sub-Output: Campaigns on volunteerism co-organized,  national networks and databases of volunteers established, and inclusion of different groups, especially people with disabilities, women and youth, in national volunteering initiatives supported to promote inclusive volunteerism and exchange of experiences.
Description: Support inclusion of different groups in national volunteering initiatives including People with Disabilities, women, and youth. Establish a national network of volunteering agencies in Bahrain and support exchange of experience's-organize a campaign on the value of volunteerism and establish a national database of volunteers in Bahrain.  Open UNV opportunities for persons with disabilities inside and outside Bahrain.
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Government of Bahrain, Government of Sweden
Implementation partners: Bahrain Ministry of Youth and Sports Affairs, Bahrain civil society
SDG Targets: 8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,17.16 Enhance the global partnership for sustainable development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the sustainable development goals in all countries, in particular developing countries.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Equal representation and  inclusion of different vulunarable groups, especially women, youth and people with disabilities, in the planned activities will be ensured.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: UNV Duty of care for all UN Volunteers is applied, the sub-output seeks to ensure the meaningful participation of  various stakeholders in activities, and the sub-output  targets patterns of discrimination, inequality or marginalization through targeted efforts to involve disadvantaged groups in volunteering initiatives.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative:
•	Bahrain was included as a case study in the report entitled “Volunteerism and the State in the Arab World: Toward Building an Inclusive Society”, being acknowledged as one of the countries in the Arab region that offers innovative models of the volunteer/State relationship that can be emulated to create more sustainable and inclusive societies.. 
 •	The Bahrain-based organization (Arab Voluntary Union) in partnership with UNV and UNFPA arranged in the 3rd Edition of Mohamed Ben Fahd International award. 22 volunteering initiatives was awarded in a regional ceremony organized at the League of Arab States premises in Cairo in December 2021. 
•	The International Volunteer Day was marked and celebrated at national level in Bahrain with a resourceful participation of the UN Resident Coordinator, and in partnership with the Youth Pioneers Society. The discussion highlighted the important role of volunteers, especially during the organization of the Asian Paralympic games, and the contribution of volunteers in supporting the development programmes in the country.
2022 Narrative: In partnership with the Arab Voluntary Union based in Bahrain, UNV took active part in the 4th edition of Mohamed Ben Fahd International award for best volunteering projects. 18 volunteering initiatives from 11 countries were selected this year to receive the award in community services.The UN system in Bahrain continued its efforts to promote volunteerism and support youth empowerment at national level. UNV together with UNIC Manama supported a session the "Volunteer work: ambition, challenges and development” conference, organized by “Sitra Society” under the patronage of the H.E. the Minister of Social Development. The conference was attended by more than 100 participants of humanitarian researchers, active social figures, along with government officials. In addition, the UN system celebrated the International Volunteer Day through a production of a promotional video featuring the efforts of volunteers in Bahrain.
